feed.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion initiates with a grim foresight into potential worst-case scenarios that could afflict the Bitcoin ecosystem, emphasizing concerns far beyond common apprehensions. The first point of concern highlights the possibility of a group stealthily gaining advanced access to certain functionalities, allowing them to surreptitiously steal coins. This scenario not only presents an economic advantage for the perpetrators but also poses a significant threat to the wider community, as it would fuel ongoing disputes about the legitimacy of such thefts, undermining trust within the system.
Further exacerbating the situation is the prospect of a well-equipped attacker, lacking actual access to an ECDLP break, inducing panic by falsely claiming their coins were stolen. This act of deception is particularly feasible with taproot coins, as opposed to those created in the initial years of Bitcoin's existence. The main goal of such attackers would be to sow enough doubt and controversy to potentially cause a chain split, driven by divergent views on how to address this fabricated threat. This scenario underscores a stark contrast from previous incidents like the DAO, where theft was transparently evident, highlighting the nuanced challenges Bitcoin faces in maintaining its integrity against not just theft, but the illusion thereof.
The conversation also introduces the concept of "disabled NUMS" in relation to taproot external keys, advocating for its role in facilitating a smoother transition to Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) within the tapleaf scripts. This approach is presented as an uncontroversial form of censorship, presumably due to its forward-looking and preventive nature against quantum computing threats.
Lastly, there's an acknowledgment of the contentious nature surrounding the idea of a burning coins softfork, suggesting that reaching consensus on such a measure would be exceedingly difficult, if not outright inadvisable. The discourse leans towards finding cryptographic solutions that enable the safe expenditure of currently hashed UTXOs, as discussed by notable figures in the field. This stance mirrors a broader sentiment that preserving the functionality of P2PK addresses amidst these transitions remains a significant challenge, underscoring a cautious yet innovative outlook towards securing Bitcoin's future against evolving technological adversities.
